Award.AwardTitle: Conference: How do we determine that something is unknowable rather than merely not yet known? - New York, NY, December 2018

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides partial support for a conference. It is an interdisciplinary, two-day, public conference that addresses an important scientific question: How we determine that something is unknowable rather than merely not yet known? Experts across a range of academic disciplines (including mathematics, cosmology, biology, medicine, economics, psychology, history, and philosophy) will discuss the criteria used to determine that a deep question cannot be answered and whether these criteria differ across fields. The conference is to occur in March 2019 at the campus of The New School for Social Research in New York City. The conference is likely to attract a large audience, from 300 to 400 people, that will include members of the public, the media, and policy makers as well as students and academics.

The questions that are to be addressed by conference participants are fundamental and of perennial importance; they require revisiting from time to time. A similar conference on this specific topic occurred at Columbia University in October 2000; it was a workshop on the known, the unknown, and the unknowable; and it was funded by the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation. A generation has passed, and it is both timely and important to address these questions again. It is likely that the conference will attract a large and broad audience, and that it will foster dialogue within and beyond the academy and serve to enhance public understanding of important social, intellectual, and political issues. Papers from the conference will constitute a special issue of Social Research: An International Quarterly. The conference proceedings will have a good chance of inspiring and affecting the discussion of the criteria that define the limits of knowledge, perhaps even leading to changes in those criteria.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
"Unknowability: How Do We Know What Cannot Be Known" was a two-day public conference held at the New School under the auspices of the Center for Public Scholarship and Social Research: An International Quarterly.

The conference had two primary goals, the first of which was to address the question of what we cannot know---a question we believe is important not only in its own right but significantly more so in light of the increased rate at which misinformation and alternative facts are disseminated as truth in the US. A better understanding of the ways in which something can possibly be known has the capacity to shape developing knowledge, scholarly research, and public education. The conference afforded a rare opportunity for renowned scholars from different fields to engage with each other and with the public on this subject.

Our second key goal concerned the question of whether there are true unknowables, and if so, what they are and how we know they are unknowable. Our exploration of this question took in the disciplines of mathematics, cosmology, biology, psychology, archaeology and philosophy, and our twofold goal was to inspire experts to look beyond the boundaries of their own fields, and to inspire the public to ask new questions about what they do not know, and possibly to consider careers in research and scholarship by way of seeking answers.

In pursuit of these goals, we brought together ten scholars from the disciplines of mathematics, cosmology, biology, psychology, archaeology, and philosophy, and invited them to address questions of unknowability in their own work, their own fields, and across fields in conversation with each other. These conversations too place over the course of three panel discussions and a keynote address, each moderated by an scholar with a unique perspective on the session's topic, and each followed by Q&A with the public audience.

The conference proceedings were livestreamed, video-recorded, and posted online (https://www.centerforpublicscholarship.org/single-post/2019/01/10/Unknowability-How-Do-We-Know-What-Cannot-Be-Known). Each of the speakers also wrote a new, publishable paper based on their presentations, and all of the papers were gathered in a special issue of Social Research: An International Quarterly devoted to the conference proceedings (https://www.socres.org/single-post/871-spring-2020-unknowability).

Presentations and discussions at the conference were lively, challenging, and thought-provoking, and will continue to invite engagement through the various formats in which they have been disseminated.
